title: Mobile suggestion
body:
I have been using boltdb to allow golang projects run on desktop and mobile.

It's a kV store and so different then postresql.
But it run great on servers, desktop and all mobiles.
It's 100% golang.

It ultimately would allow abot to run on mobile.

Not sure how the maintainer ( s) feel about this.

But it allows having master / master data replication by using raft, which is very useful because users can run and edit whilst offline. New records will get merged when back online.

Also I use storm as a nice wrapper on top of boltdb. It very easy.

Performance wise it's also very fast in reads.

Anyway, enough said about it. It really comes down to if portability to mobile is wanted

title: Suggester for better stemmer
body:
Have a look at bleve.

It's a great golang library with stemmer that handle all languages.

It uses boltdb underneath but that's not needed to help improve the stemmer functionality.

title: Update README.md
body: Add cd instruction to README.

title: New CLI

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body:
The current workflow for Abot is a bit of a pain. Abot's designed to work with plugins, so you don't need to modify the internals, but all of `/core` and `/shared` are still included with every Abot. Running multiple Abot projects on the same machine is tough.

To fix this, we're replacing the Abot CLI tool to be similar to the best parts of working with Rails and NPM/Node. If you've used either of those, you'll be right at home.

Now you'll install Abot on your computer via `go get`, then you'll be able to create new projects. Rebuilding the project no longer rebuilds the `abot` binary--just your project. This means that if something goes wrong, the `abot` command will keep working. There's also much easier plugin testing as well, which will enable us to automate plugin integration tests on itsabot.org without complex contain plugin integration tests on itsabot.org without complex containerization and security measures.

I've written a guide on the new plugin CLI here: https://github.com/itsabot/abot/wiki/Understanding-the-CLI

title: Add new plugin API

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body:
There’s going to be a new, much simpler plugin API. You can see an example [here](https://gist.github.com/egtann/8dc174ab9fdc776e4fabc0356d15d772). Notably, Command+Object triggers will now be assembled automatically from example sentences. Read the comments in the linked example—it’s really powerful. The current API will be deprecated but not removed until v1.0.

This should lay the groundwork for a visual plugin builder with a drag-and-drop interface.

title: Automatic spelling correction and Emoji Support

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body: Humans are rarely precise typists, so Abot v0.3 will add support for spelling auto-correction and expand slang (e.g. "ur," "lol") and emoji into the terms they represent (e.g. happy, sad, or snowman).

title: Centralize user-facing strings

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body: Strings used within Abot that are displayed to users, e.g. "I'm sorry, I didn't understand that." should be pulled out of the code and moved to a strings.go file located somewhere in `/base`, for easy modification.

title: Response panel improvements

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body: Add equal support in the response panel for email, web and other communication channels

title: Translation Plugin

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body: Enable translation from and to any common language automatically.

title: Handle corner case for plugin settings
Remove Procfile, update dependencies
body: You'll likely need to recreate your Procfile after pulling this change. There was no reason to have it in version control.

title: Add usage examples and help to plugins
body: Abot will now reply to users with helpful tips on what to say when confused or when a user says some variation on "help"

title: Add settings API
body:
To make plugin installation easier, environment variables that plugins depend upon have been moved to a specific Settings API. Instead of using `os.Getenv`, plugins must now use `p.GetSetting()`. Those settings must also be declared in your plugin.json per the updated spec: https://github.com/itsabot/abot/wiki/plugin.json-Spec

With this change, you'll be able to edit plugin-specific variables via the admin panel (like API keys), and itsabot.org can provide more helpful (and complete) install instructions.

title: Authentication flows to give a consistent experience to user across multiple platforms
body:
We'd like to show how user authentication works with existing user databases. You should be able to provide a consistent user experience to your users (remembering their names, shipping addresses, etc.) as they switch from messaging Abot on SMS to Facebook Messenger, email, or any other service.

The challenge is that user identifiers across platforms like Telegram, SMS & Facebook differ. e.g. SMS uses phone number, and Telegram uses username or user id. To identify the same user across these different services takes some customization.

We'd like some guides in markdown format detailing sample authentication flows across SMS, email, and webhooks (e.g. Facebook Messenger, Telegram, etc.) to be added to the wiki.

For example, a guide for an SMS authentication flow might look like this:
1. SMS that user a link to your website and ask that he/she logs in. (include sample code. this would probably be handled in a state with SkipIfComplete. The Complete check would confirm that HasMemory("authenticated"))
2. On your server, when he logs in:
   - Save the SMS phone number from the user.
   - Send a text message back from Abot's phone number to get the user back in the SMS flow. "Thanks for logging in! How can I help you today?"
3. Write a plugin that listens for the `PostProcessing` event. In that event, make a GET request to your server to confirm if that phone number is currently authenticated. If so, `SetMemory("authenticated", true)`, or `DeleteMemory("authenticated")` if not.

It's then up to your server to decide when the user is no longer authenticated. Should it time out after 30 minutes? 12 hours? 2 weeks? Should it require authentication each time an important transaction is performed, such as a purchase?

body: The Iterate task enables you to easily iterate over a []string in your plugins' state machines.

title: Prevent creation of plugin.go in current dir
Improve time parsing, fix scheduled events
Add ABOT_PATH env variable support
body:
This change enables you to work on Abot from any directory in your GOPATH by passing by setting the ABOT_PATH env variable, either in abot.env (for a single install) or ~/.bashrc (global default).

This means you can now fork Abot and develop it in the appropriate directory in your filesystem.

title: Remove contactable interface, admin type
body: Removing unused code.

title: Add response panel with SMS support
body:
Additionally, clean up old and dead code and shrink core's exported API.
A number of gometalinter warnings are fixed as well.

title: Admin Dashboard
body:
I'm building an admin dashboard to replace the old (and not very useful) getting started page. Here's a WIP screenshot.

Goals of mine are to:
- Help you stay up-to-date, ensuring you're running the latest Abot version
- Help you set up your Abot completely with all the new functionality that's being added (Account Connect, etc.), as well as surface that new functionality after each update
- Showcase the plugins you've installed and connect you to find more
- Show basic usage stats (with support later for graphs/visualizations)

I'd love any feedback. Right now it's just front-end work, so it's all still pretty flexible.

![Admin Dashboard](http://i.imgur.com/k7uNOkP.png)

title: Use new plugin API, fix bugs
body:
1. [Breaking Changes] Simplified plugin API
   - Removed Run/FollowUp functions
   - Renamed Vocab to Keywords and VocabHandler to KeywordHandler, which better reflects their purposes
   - Triggers are now automatically generated for the plugin based on Keywords
   - Defining additional triggers beyond keywords (i.e. to route to your state machine, but not any keyword handler) is now optional and can be done using plugin.NewTrigger()
   - Every plugin now has a state machine that's managed by Abot automatically
     - You should use p.SM to access a pre-configured state machine, rather than building your own.
   - Moved Memory API from the state machine to plugins to better reflect the relationship between memory and the plugin (memory belongs to plugins -- the state machine has nothing to do with
     it.)
     - Now use p.GetMemory() and p.SetMemory()
   - Branching conversations are still supported
     - Use p.SetBranches(func(in *dt.Msg) []dt.State) to use
       branching conversations. Change the returned []dt.State based
       on flags set in memory or by the *dt.Msg passed in. Abot will set the flags on a per-user, per-message basis based upon the return of this function. By default, this does not have to be implemented.
2. Fixed a large number of state machine bugs
3. Added support for routing to plugins and keyword handlers based on trained
   Intents

You can see an example implementation of the latest changes at https://github.com/egtann/plugin_weather. Docs will follow.

title: Support multiple plugins per auth token
Better install process
body:
Part of the install process is to create an admin user, but that's hidden away as a Postgres flag users would almost never discover.

When there are no users in the DB, `localhost:4200` should show a "Create an Admin" screen, requiring the user choose an email and password for admin logins. Only after there's an admin in the database should it allow you to use the Abot web interface. The cmd/setup.sh script (and potentially cmd/dbsetup.sh as well) should be modified to also mention creating an _admin_ account as the next step.

title: Better rollbacks when `abot plugin install` fails
body:
Installing plugins can fail for any number of reasons (lack of internet connection, other site isn't up, a typo in your dependencies, etc.), but right now we just error out immediately. If you have an incomplete `plugins.go` file as a result, compiling will fail.

We should handle errors in `installPlugins()` like so:

``` go
if err := installPlugins(); err != nil { ... }
```

 and delete the `plugins.go` file we created.

title: Voice support
body:
It'd be great to build an interface that enables communication from Abot via voice.

Whoever wants to tackle this would have to design an interface to communicate with arbitrary voice recognition APIs (Google, Nuance, etc.), then implement that interface in a driver for at least one of those.

To get started, take a look at one of the existing interfaces, such as the SMS interface. Then see how a driver integrates with it by implementing that SMS interface: Twilio driver.

title: Bot platform compatibility (Facebook, Slack, etc.)
body:
It'd be great to build an interface that enables communication from Abot via Facebook's Bot platform or any other. Facebook bots, Slack bots, etc. built using Abot would be able to use our language tools, state management, and memory API. They'd also benefit from integrating with the other platforms through user discovery, and by having their users communicate with the bot on the platforms they use already (like Slack).

Whoever wants to tackle this would have to design an interface to communicate with arbitrary HTTP bot platforms (Kik, Facebook, Telegram, Slack, etc.), then implement that interface in a driver for at least one platform--ideally Facebook, but any are helpful.

To get started, take a look at one of the existing interfaces, such as the [SMS interface](https://github.com/itsabot/abot/tree/master/shared/interface/sms). Then see how a driver integrates with it by _implementing_ that SMS interface: [Twilio driver](https://github.com/itsabot/twilio/blob/master/twilio.go).

title: Add training interface, new admin panel
Fix bugs
body: This fixes a number of bugs in tokenization and the state machine in addition to fixing parts of deploying to Heroku and plugin installs.

title: Fix statemachine.LoadState, formatting
body: Use UserID if available (otherwise FlexID and FlexIDType) to identify the user and save memories.

title: Fix bugs in ExtractCities
body: ExtractCities will now never return before running `rows.Close`. It also now checks for an error with `rows.Err()` and returns the correct response if there are no cities: `ErrNotFound`. This brings ExtractCities in line with the rest of the Extract APIs.

title: Fix state machine bugs
body: Fixes several bugs related to state machines and memory.

title: Customize OPTIONS response, allow cross-origin
body: Enable any domain by default to make requests to Abot's primary route handler. This allows things like https://github.com/DaleWebb/abot-widget to communicate from your browser to Abot.

title: Fix missing plugins.go bug
body: This fixes a bug that occasionally prevents `abot p install` and other commands from running when the generated `plugins.go` is missing.

title: Remove plugin_onboard from routing
body: Update the README and remove references to a no-longer-necessary plugin from the code. Non-users are now able to speak to Abot, and it's up to each plugin to decide whether a login is needed.

title: Fix scheduled event bug
body: Prevents the logged error message on each run about failing to schedule an event.

title: Load env variables in tests
body: Fixes tests running locally by loading your abot.env. To keep TravisCI from complaining, it doesn't error out if the abot.env file is missing--it simply logs and continues.

title: Support FlexID for memories and add session-based FlexIDType
Plugins of other users can be published

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body:
I can publish a plugin on behalf of another user. This is not a desirable behavior.

To combat this, we'll add a required "Maintainer" key on `plugin.json` which must have the itsabot.org registered email you intend to publish plugins under. It's similar to how some services require DNS changes to demonstrate proof-of-ownership over a domain. Just like that, we'll require you to set a verifiable value in something that only you (or people to whom you give access) can control. Instead of DNS, it's your plugin.json.

This is susceptible to another attack, though, where I register on itsabot.org with an email that's not mine, but one that matches a known Maintainer email, so it'll allow falsely publishing a plugin under that email. To solve that, we'll have to implement email verification from itsabot.org to prove ownership over the email.

With these two steps, we can verify that you own the plugin you're publishing!

title: Find city when the city is not capitalized
body: Let me know your thoughts and if you'd like anything changed. (currently using the branch locally)

title: Change type of sentence(messages table) to TEXT
body: Fixes #67

title: Update README.md

title: Fix Heroku deploys
body:
Make a number of modifications to support deploying to Heroku and other
platforms. Since platforms like Heroku delete data in the filesystem after their
build step, each plugin's plugin.json file is embedded into the generated
plugins.go on install.

title: ImportPath doesn't affect every path
body:
There are a number of places in the codebase where `filepath.Join(..., "github.com", "itsabot", "abot", ...)` is called, rather than using the `conf.ImportPath` defined in plugins.json.

This isn't a straightforward fix, since the plugins themselves need access to that variable on `init()` and we can't control when they boot. This seems like a great use for blocking channels, then. We can hide the channel's complexity within the existing plugin.New API, having the plugin wait until it receives the OK from core that the ImportPath variable is set and ready to use.

title: Create flexid from email on user signup
body: Solving #70

title: Email FlexID not created on signup
Email driver for receiving and sending emails
body:
Created email interface, similar to the SMS interface, that can receive and send emails.

Implemented with a Mailgun plugin at https://github.com/DaleWebb/mailgun

title: Training Interface Mockup
body:
![Training Interface Mockup](http://i.imgur.com/7RZmMg7.png)

Here's my thinking for the first version of the training interface, which will enable you to train your Abot:
- Plugins should be trained individually. That is, I train the `alarm` and `restaurants` plugins separately.
- Training data of published plugins must be shared to enable those plugins to work. I'm thinking of supporting two models simultaneously:
  1. Encode training data into a text file and save it with the plugin (open-source trained model)
  2. Make it available via an external HTTP request (closed-source trained model). This will enable developers to charge money or protect particularly complex trained models.
- The Intent mentioned here would be available to plugins via StructuredInput.
- Over time we can expand this design with:
  - In-line testing, so you can quickly iterate without jumping back to the console, perhaps via a keyboard shortcut.
  - The ability to add additional, custom fields beyond Intent.
  - Auto-completion on the field (set_alarm, disable_alarm, etc.) with past values.
  - Display real user requests to that plugin, with requests that the plugin couldn't handle sorted to the top.

Would love feedback!

title: Messages should not be limited to 255 chars
body: This is because the underlying column has type `character varying(255)`.

title: Plugins can interrupt each other
body:
If you're in a plugin, and just happen to give a follow-up message that matches the trigger for another plugin, you'll be switched over to that plugin.

This is extremely unintuitive and not desired. The expectation is I continue to interact with the current plugin until it finishes or I abort.

title: Allow non-users to message Abot
body:
This also removes the `ErrMissingUser`, since that's no longer an error. It's now fine to message Abot from an unfamiliar phone number. If a plugin wants to ensure a user signs up before that user reaches some secure point (a banking plugin? shopping?), the plugin can include the `RequestSignup` task in its state machine.

Alternatively, a plugin could enforce logins globally (across all plugins) by registering event listeners to override requests sent by unregistered users.

Everyone will want to run the included migration if they're pulling in this change.

title: Protocol Buffers
body:
I propose we switch our data serialization format from JSON to Protocol Buffers.

They:
-     are simpler
-     are 3 to 10 times smaller
-     are 20 to 100 times faster
-     are less ambiguous
-     generate data access classes that are easier to use programmatically

They require you to write a schema for your storage stuct, but that's trivial.

[Link to more info](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/overview)

title: Add StateMachine.DeleteMemory
body: Fixes #58.

title: Increment value of sm.state when SkipIfComplete
body:
Otherwise, an infinite loop occurs.

Fixes #57

title: Switch cookie library, update to match new API
body:
Switch the cookie library to one with a more permissive license.

Also change call sites to reflect the changed API (get vs. getItem, set
vs. setItem, expire vs. removeItem).

Fixes #31

title: HasMemory is broken
body: `StateMachine.HasMemory()` doesn't work as advertised. It's doing a check on a length of the byte buffer, which is not empty for a JSON marshaled string. It needs to be marshaled to a string before this check is done.

title: Setting SkipIfComplete to true causes an infinite loop
body: line 191 of `state_machine.go` calls return `sm.Next(in)` without ever incrementing the value of `sm.state.`

title: How do I handle asking for information only when needed?
body:
The current implementation of the state machine requires that `StateMachine.Next()` be called twice. Once so that the code in `OnEntry()` is run and then on the subsequent call, `OnInput()` and `OnComplete()`. I noticed that there is a `SkipIfComplete`, but using it seems wrong.

For example, I want to support the following homogeneously:
- What's the weather in Seattle?
  - bot: The weather is 55 degrees and cloudy.
- What's the weather?
  - bot: What city do you want the weather for?
  - me: Seattle
  - bot: The weather is 55 degrees and cloudy.

What I'm inclined to do is just to use `SkipIfComplete` and do all the logic within `Complete()`. What's the approach that you would suggest?

title: Extract API Fix
body:
I was writing a plugin for Abot and found that the ExtractCurrency function was multiplying floats by 100 and returning an int instead of letting plugin authors deal with the desired float (which they can format later). 

So I fixed that, and made the rest of the Extract API more idiomatic.

title: Handle multiple entries in GOPATH
body: This fixes #45

title: Install Script
body:
Not sure if you're hard pressed on piping a file to sh, but if you're not and you're willing to require that users have golang already installed...

Then just get them to execute `wget https://github.com/itsabot/abot/abot_install.go && go run abot_install.go`

The script puts abot in the GOPATH, and runs cmd/setup. If you want it to do more, just let me know.

title: Handle binaries like images
body: Do you see a chance to also process binary files like images? They might get send to the bot e.g. via Slack and I'd love to handle them as well.

title: Add support for multiple directories in $GOPATH
body: F.e. when one sets `GOPATH=/usr/local/go:/home/hashworks/go` abot won't start because it will look for `/usr/local/go:/home/hashworks/go/src/github.com/itsabot/abot/plugins.json`.

title: Make cookies secure only in production
`abot plugin install` fails: GLOCKFILE not found
body:
I'm getting an error while running `abot plugin install`, whether manually or through `cmd/setup.sh`:

```
$ abot plugin install
Fetching 1 plugins...
WARN: 500 - 500 Internal Server Error
Installing plugins...
error creating %!!(MISSING)s(func(string) string=0x410d00): open /home/yuri/projects/src/home/yuri/projects/src/github.com/itsabot/abot/GLOCKFILE: no such file or directory

exit status 1
```

```
$ cmd/setup.sh
    [ok] checking for go binary
    [ok] checking GOPATH
    [ok] installing dependency manager
    [ok] syncing dependencies
    [ok] installing glock hook
    [ok] installing abot
    [ok] checking for postgres
    [ok] checking for psql binary
    [ok] checking for postgres user
    [ok] checking for abot database
    [ok] checking for abot_test database
  [warn] running abot migrations
database migrations failed
if the database has already been migrated, you can ignore this message

  [warn] running abot_test migrations
database migrations failed
if the database has already been migrated, you can ignore this message

    [ok] checking if abot database is seeded
    [ok] checking if abot_test database is seeded
    [ok] generating environment file
   [err] installing abot plugins

failed cmd:
         abot plugin install

Fetching 1 plugins...
WARN: 500 - 500 Internal Server Error
Installing plugins...
error creating %!!(MISSING)s(func(string) string=0x410d00): open /home/yuri/projects/src/home/yuri/projects/src/github.com/itsabot/abot/GLOCKFILE: no such file or directory

exit status 1
```

As you can see, the problem is that GLOCKFILE couldn't be found, because it's supposed to be at location which is constructed incorrectly: `/home/yuri/projects/src/home/yuri/projects/src/github.com/itsabot/abot/GLOCKFILE` should be `/home/yuri/projects/src/github.com/itsabot/abot/GLOCKFILE`, which exists.

Notice that `$GOPATH/src` (`/home/yuri/projects/src`) is added to the glockfile location - is it possible to remove it? Thanks

title: Modify setup scripts to accept database parameters
body:
allowing an optional argument to specify the database connection
parameters allows different connection methods to be used. additionally,
along with some script refactoring, it allows the database to be setup
separately from the abot server.

to support this, cmd/setup.sh was refactored into the following scripts:
- cmd/setup.sh
- cmd/dbsetup.sh
- cmd/helper_functions.sh

cmd/setup.sh now accepts an optional argument for the database
connection parameters. if no argument is given, it assumes sane
defaults. in both cases, the database parameters are saved in abot.env
under ABOT_DATABASE_URL. during setup, if the psql binary is
unavailable, the script will skip the database setup. it assumes it was
handled externally. otherwise, cmd/dbsetup.sh is called with the same
connection argument (if any) that this script was called with. beyond
that, code was refactored into cmd/dbsetup.sh and
cmd/helper_functions.sh and some general cleanup performed.

cmd/dbsetup.sh contains all the logic for setting up the abot databases.
it also accepts the same optional argument as cmd/setup.sh. this allows
the database to be setup on a different machine than the abot server.
this script now encapsulates the dependency on the psql binary.

cmd/helper_functions.sh contains functions that help with running setup
commands, pretty printing messages, and database parameter parsing. this
allows code re-use between cmd/setup.sh and cmd/dbsetup.sh, which may be
called independently.

the following changes were made to the go code-base:

abot.go:loadEnvVars() is now in core/boot.go:LoadEnvVars(). since the
database connection relies on the ABOT_DATABASE_URL environment
variable, this function needs to be available for plugins/external
packages.

core/boot.go:ConnectDB() now uses the ABOT_DATABASE_URL environment
variable exclusively. if ABOT_DATABASE_URL is empty, it applies
defaults.

shared/plugin/plugin.go:connectDB() is gone. now it uses the code in
core/boot.go:ConnectDB()

parameters allows different connection methods to be used. additionally,
along with some script refactoring, it allows the database to be setup

connection parameters. if no argument is given, it assumes sane

under ABOT_DATABASE_URL. during setup, if the psql binary is
unavailable, the script will skip the database setup. it assumes it was
handled externally. otherwise, cmd/dbsetup.sh is called with the same
connection argument (if any) that this script was called with. beyond
that, code was refactored into cmd/dbsetup.sh and
cmd/helper_functions.sh and some general cleanup performed.

cmd/dbsetup.sh contains all the logic for setting up the abot databases.
it also accepts the same optional argument as cmd/setup.sh. this allows
the database to be setup on a different machine than the abot server.
this script now encapsulates the dependency on the psql binary.

cmd/helper_functions.sh contains functions that help with running setup
commands, pretty printing messages, and database parameter parsing. this
allows code re-use between cmd/setup.sh and cmd/dbsetup.sh, which may be
called independently.

the following changes were made to the go code-base:

abot.go:loadEnvVars() is now in core/boot.go:LoadEnvVars(). since the
database connection relies on the ABOT_DATABASE_URL environment
variable, this function needs to be available for plugins/external
packages.

core/boot.go:ConnectDB() now uses the ABOT_DATABASE_URL environment
variable exclusively. if ABOT_DATABASE_URL is empty, it applies
defaults.

shared/plugin/plugin.go:connectDB() is gone. now it uses the code in
core/boot.go:ConnectDB()

title: Remove vendor/cookie.js
body:
Cookie.js (`assets/vendor/js/cookie.js`) is using an incompatible GPLv3 license. Rewrite it from scratch under MIT ensuring that no code breaks in the front-end. The API may change (it may have to), but any JavaScript that calls it should reflect that change.

This is a good first issue for new contributors.

title: Add PreProcessing Plugin Event
body:
This will allow plugins to, for example, translate text back and forth to multiple languages on the fly, remembering which language each user is speaking.

Function signature: `func(cmd *string, u *dt.User)`

title: Return 401 unauthorized if missing auth cookies
body: This refers to #27. The correct HTTP status code is now returned when cookies are missing from a request during authentication.

Cheers,
Davide

title: Return 500s in the event of errors on signup
body:
If the form validation goes through but there's an error at the database
level, or with creating the CSRF token, then return a 500.

We shouldn't allow the user to proceed, but it's not necessarily the
case that they've entered bad data (e.g. pg server being down would also
cause a failure).

Fixes #18

title: failed to process text missing user
body:
It's all setup. I started the server and registered a user.
but then when I try to communicate with abot

```
abot console +13105555555
> Hi
Something went wrong with my wiring... I'll get that fixed up soon.
> hi baby 
Something went wrong with my wiring... I'll get that fixed up soon.
> 
```

and on the server it says:

```
abot server
2016/03/31 23:45:39 started Abot
2016/03/31 23:45:43 failed to process text missing user
2016/03/31 23:46:39 failed to queue scheduled event missing destination name id
2016/03/31 23:47:02 failed to process text missing user
```

So a `failed to process text missing user` for every message I send to abot.

title: error while installing `[err] syncing dependencies`
body:
```
    [ok] checking for go binary
    [ok] checking GOPATH
    [ok] installing dependency manager
   [err] syncing dependencies

failed cmd:
         glock sync 'github.com/itsabot/abot'

bash: glock: command not found
```

title: Dockerize
body:
I tried to dockerize abot, but the postgres check on setup is by process(**ps ax -o comm | grep -q '^postgres')**. The postgres check should be a telnet on postgres port.

Step 15 : RUN ./cmd/setup.sh
 ---> Running in 63fd2e6a3688
    [ok] checking for go binary
    [ok] checking GOPATH
    [ok] installing dependency manager
    [ok] syncing dependencies
    [ok] installing glock hook
    [ok] installing abot
   [err] checking for postgres

failed cmd:
         ps ax -o comm | grep -q '^postgres'

title: Password resets fail

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Improve developer quality of life, strengthen Abot's mastery over natural language, and core improvements supporting multiple communication channels.

body:
### Current behavior

User profile has a "Change password" link, but that link doesn't work.
### Desired behavior
- If there's an emailsender driver installed: change password should send an email to reset the user's password with visual confirmation
- If there's no emailsender driver installed: Display instructions to the user on how to install an emailsender driver.

This is a mentor bug, meaning that if you'd like to contribute a fix but you're unsure how to complete the entire task or would like another set of eyes to review your work, please comment on the issue, and I'll help!

title: Fix signup, form parsing issues, add styling
Multiple handles for the same response
Parsing form values doesn't seem to be working correctly in the request handlers
body:
I've been playing around with this but haven't quite gotten a patch together yet. 

It seems like there's an issue with decoding the form values from a JSON post request - namely, it doesn't see the payload as form values and so values (e.g. name, email, fid) are all blank when going to read them.

Entirely possible this is an OS issue: I haven't tried on any other OS (running OS X 10.11.3).

I suspect it might be more robust to treat the payload as JSON and use a JSON decoder instead, but I'm mostly curious if other people are having the same issue.

title: Send back 400 errors for form validation errors
body:
Form validation errors should trigger 400s, not 200s. Otherwise,
the user can be taken to e.g. the post-signup page even though their
registration wasn't successful.

title: Update WS endpoint
body:
It seems like the intention was to hit "/ws", not "/_/cmd/ws".

Hitting the latter returns errors over and over again (about receiving a
200 code), whereas the former seems to give the correct behavior
(establishes a websocket connection and switches protocols after the initial
request).

title: [err] syncing dependencies, failed cmd: glock sync 'github.com/itsabot/abot'
body:
```
$ rpm -q golang-bin
golang-bin-1.5.3-1.fc23.x86_64
$ cd go
$ export GOPATH=$PWD
$ go get github.com/itsabot/abot
$ cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/itsabot/abot
$ cmd/setup.sh
    [ok] checking for go binary
    [ok] checking GOPATH
    [ok] installing dependency manager
   [err] syncing dependencies

failed cmd:
         glock sync 'github.com/itsabot/abot'

bash: glock: command not found
```

title: Use RethinkDB instead of PostgreSQL
body: If I would like to use RethinkDB instead of PostgreSQL would it be a easy switch? Can you point the direction on where I should look? The main reason for considering RethinkDB is due to its changefeed feature. https://rethinkdb.com/docs/changefeeds/ruby/

title: updates cmd/setup.sh and environment variable loading
body:
modifications to cmd/setup.sh:
- improves the "postgres running" check
- add checks for go binary, psql binary, and GOPATH
- fixes osx/linux compatibility issues with the urandom/tr command
- makes the terminal output prettier
- exports necessary environment variables to a project local "abot.env" file
  this replaces the previous behavior of inserting the variables into the
  users .bashrc/.bash_profile

modifications to abot.go:
- uses values from the new "abot.env" file to update the environment.
  note: it will only update environment variables that are not already set

modifications to .gitignore:
- adds abot.env: it contains the server secret
- adds plugins.go: it is dynamically generated

title: Change tr invocation in setup script
body:
### Preface

Hi,

First and foremost: Apologies if this isn't the correct workflow for opening a pull request. The contributing page made it seem like this was an appropriate way to make relatively minor contributions, but if there are steps I should've taken first (like posting on the mailing list), I can absolutely do that and close this.
### Update to the `tr` call in the setup script

I'm proposing a couple of changes to the `tr` call in the setup script: One enhancement and one small fix for users trying to run the setup script on OS X (I'm running 10.11.3, but I imagine it affects previous OS X versions as well).
1. Use [:alnum:] instead of enumerating the characters. Also add a small subset of punctuation characters that won't cause horrible problems, but allow a slightly larger universe of characters to create the secret from.
2. Set `LC_CTYPE`. In OS X, at least, `tr` will fail miserably when reading from `/dev/urandom`. I suppose this is probably because `tr` encounters non-UTF sequences in `/dev/urandom` and then bails out. I don't think this change will affect other OSes, but I could certainly wrap this in an `$OSTYPE` check if it eases anyone's mind.
### Update the README

This is explained in the commit, but I think the README should say `source cmd/setup.sh` instead of just `cmd/setup.sh`

title: Remove extra `.git` extension for install
body:
`go get` is finicky, and will give an error:

`package github.com/itsabot/abot.git: invalid version control suffix in github.com/ path`

title: Use httprouter instead of echo. Add tests.
